Take a basis $\mathscr{B}$
${[x]}_\mathscr{B}$, the coordinate of $x$ with respect to $\mathscr{B}$, is the coordinates necessary to represent $x$ in that basis.

Let $\mathscr{B} = \{ u_1, \dots, u_n \}$ be a basis for $\mathbb{R}^n$
If $y = \sum{y_iu_i}$, then ${[y]}_\mathscr{B} = \matrixstart y_i \\ \vdots \\ y_n \matrixend$

Now define $U = \matrixstart u_1 & \dots & u_n \matrixend \in \mathbb{R}^n$
$U{[y]}_\mathscr{B} = y$

$U$ is a change of basis matrix that allows us to switch from $\mathscr{B} \to \mathscr{I}$ ($I$, the standard basis)
That is, (informally) $U : \mathscr{B} \to \mathscr{I}$

$U^{-1}$, if it exists, is $U^{-1} : \mathscr{I} \to \mathscr{B}$

$x = U{[x]}_\mathscr{B}$
${[x]}_\mathscr{B} = U^{-1}x$

Two bases $\mathscr{B}_1, \mathscr{B}_2$ given by matrices $U,V$
${[x]}_{\mathscr{B}_2} = V^{-1}U{[x]}_{\mathscr{B}_1}$
${[x]}_{\mathscr{B}_1} = U^{-1}V{[x]}_{\mathscr{B}_2}$


Now suppose $S$ is a subspace of $\mathbb{R}^n$ with bases $\mathscr{B}_1 = \matrixstart u_1 & \dots & u_k \matrixend, \mathscr{B}_2 = \matrixstart v_1 & \dots & v_k \matrixend, k \leq n$

Let $C = \matrixstart {[u_1]}_{\mathscr{B}_2} & \dots & {[u_k]}_{\mathscr{B}_2} \matrixend$
${[x]}_{\mathscr{B}_2} = C{[x]}_{\mathscr{B}_1}$
